nova/tests/functional/libvirt/integrated.message: Does SUSE require that you do this?

Honestly I don't know.  I literally copied the header of an existing file (functional/integrated_helpers.py), but thought it was wrong to use the copyright name from it (Justin Santa Barbara) since this is a brand new file which has little to do with them.

Having said that, it seems (and I suspect you'll agree based on our previous IRC conversations) like total bullshit putting individuals or organizations at the top of these files, since they tend to be a big amalgamation of work from many different people and organizations. Clearly the git history is a far better way to track copyright ownership.

I'll ditch it, but guidance is very welcome if there's something better to put here. If you're wondering why I didn't put my own name, well SUSE's paying me to do this so it seems fairer that they should get any copyright assignment.  That might even be in my contract but it seems like a grey area anyway when it comes to FOSS (e.g. I don't believe they should have any claim to hacking done in my spare time, I'm free to hack on OpenStack outside working hours, and my hours are pretty fluid anyway ...)
or this? There was a movement a while back to stop saying this.

I did just find https://docs.openstack.org/hacking/latest/user/hacking.html#openstack-licensing which seems to imply that I could just ditch these first two lines, but it would be better if there was an explicit policy documented.

cinderlib/objects.py.message:
Since we want it defined in all cases we may use something like:

  attach_mode=kwargs.get('attach_mode', 'rw')

That would not be correct, as it would break in the same way it does now, because attach_mode is passed twice.

These are 2 other ways we could achieve the same idea that would work:

  attach_mode=kwargs.pop('attach_mode', 'rw')

or

  kwargs.setdefault('attach_mode', 'rw')


But I still prefer to leave the decision of setting a default to other parts of the code.

I would suggest to move this in __init__ so we avoid any issue if someone try to get conn_info from self._ovo.connection_info. Also that is avoiding to recalculate this each time this "property" is called.

The reason why it's not in the init is because we could have a call to __init__ that doesn't have the `connection_info` set yet, and at some point it will have the data and we'll want to add the access_mode.  That's why it's here.

I believe the most important case is the load of objects from persistence, so I'm going to double check that's the only case and look for an alternative to set it in the `__init__` method.
data can be None here, right? You probably need to move this all part of code under line 669.

OK thanks. Why do you use 'self.conn_info.get('data')' it suggests the value returned can be None. Don't you think we could use 'self.conn_info['data']' to avoid misunderstood?

Also I have question, what will happen if 'self._ovo.attach_mode' is set when 'self.attach_mode' as-well?

`.get('data')` suggests the value may not be present, not that when it is present it can be `None`.

`self.attach_mode` is the same as `self._ovo.attach_mode`, the `__getattr__` method does the conversion, so when I write in the if `self.attach_mode` is the short version of `self._ovo.attach_mode`.

It should never be None, worst case it would be an empty dict, and probably not even that.

And moving this below the line you suggest would make us not set a default attach_mode when data is an empty dict.
This part make me worry since if 'attach_mode' is not set an exception will be raised. Also why checking 'data' if at least it will be an empty dict?
Perfect thanks for taking the time.

`attach_mode` will always be set, that's the whole point of L666-L667.

data could be None if the key was not present on L664.
You are confusing me. It's basically the point I'm trying to indicate to you, line L667, data could be None. So data.get(...) will fail badly.
Now I get what you meant. I'll update L664 to return a default value when not present.
Really this looks to hacky and difficult to review for new contributors, can you add at least a comment? Thanks.

Thanks for the reference Gorka. It's not the function itself. Adding piece of code everywhere just to fix an issue does not not look right and a good way to maintain a library, more of that when you are expecting contributors to involve on it.

That is why I'm suggesting to you to indicate why your are setting this here.
A comment on `setdefault`? It's basic python, I believe a comment is not warranted? https://docs.python.org/2/library/stdtypes.html#dict.setdefault

What I don't understand is how is it hacky and what the comment should say: "Setting access_mode if not present in the connection info to make sure we always have it present, even if the connection info is added after initialization"?

I can add that comment, or one on the lines of it, but I'm not sure it adds that much value.
Thanks for this.
Do we really need the condition now? What about to just set it in all case?

We can set in all cases, but when the 'data' key is not present we will be adding it to a local dictionary, so it will not be really saved in the connection information, which may be confusing when debugging things.

Either way looks good to me.  One is more "technically correct" and the other is more readable.
OK your choice.

Hmm, OK, so this is new. Let's say I'm running with --all-cells and --until-complete, but haven't specified --max_rows, so by default it's going to archive in batches of 1000 until there is nothing more to archive.

Now let's say I have these cells with number of archive-able records:

* cell0: 500
* cell1: 2000
* cell2: 1500

That means I'd have something like this for max_rows_to_archive, right?

* cell0: single pass, archive 500 records, so max_rows_to_archive=1000-500=500.

* cell1: it's going to iterate 4 times in batches of 500, right? Rather than 2 iterations of 1000?

* cell2: since max_rows (1000) is not greater than total_rows_archived at this point (2500), max_rows_to_archive would still be 500 and we'd iterate 3 times to archive cell2.

I was wondering if we had a bug before with --max_rows and --until-complete, but we wouldn't because --until-complete means keep going until there is nothing more, which it still is, but the batch size is potentially different now.

It seems the logic here is trying to account for the case that --until-complete is *not* specified so we don't want to go over --max_rows when doing --all-cells, but shouldn't this logic not apply in the --until-complete case?

Thanks for pointing this out. I had removed the until_complete condition based on comments on PS60, not realizing what Kevin's code comment was getting at. Yeah anyOf is not the right one here. 

- oneOf matches exactly one schema and fail if it match nore than one schema
- anyOf can match one or more schemas. So mixed elements matching mix of both schema is pass.

In case of schema you mentioned, properties will be applied only if 'unshelve' is dict not in case of null so below values will pass:

pass:
 {'unshelve': null}
 {'unshelve': {}}
 {'unshelve': {'availability_zone': 'nova'}}

anything else will fail.

So we need to restrict {} by adding 'required': ['availability_zone']

which means either it is null otherwise pass 'availability_zone'.

Is this an issue where we're trying to hit ironic before ironic api is actually available? Because later things seem to be fine.

I thought there was some code in the driver (added by jroll?) that waited for the "hypervisor" to be ready.

Having said that, before this change we also hit VirtDriverNotReady tracebacks in the logs depending on when the compute service is started before ironic is available:

http://logs.openstack.org/26/551026/4/check/ironic-tempest-ipa-wholedisk-bios-agent_ipmitool-tinyipa/e372b1b/controller/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz#_Jul_23_17_25_16_947848

The difference seems to be the new code kills the service on startup whereas the thing before didn't (it was bombing out in a periodic). I think the previous thing only doesn't kill the service because it's handled here:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/383a4cf3710b5da2fe0b580bc25783ec8fefed48/nova/compute/manager.py#L8290

As seen in the logs:

http://logs.openstack.org/26/551026/4/check/ironic-tempest-ipa-wholedisk-bios-agent_ipmitool-tinyipa/e372b1b/controller/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz#_Jul_23_17_24_28_825895

So I guess the question is, should we similarly swallow and not kill the service if we hit the sdk connection error and try to reconnect later if we can, maybe using a property method for the ironicconn attribute so we can make the connection on first attempt if we haven't successfully connected yet? Or just say f it, if the "hypervisor" isn't available we should fail to start the service (would the libvirt driver fail to start if we can't connect to libvirtd? I'm guessing yes).

Whoops, that being
 if self._ironicconn is None:

Would this be a better place to setup the sdk connection? Probably not, that's actually called before ComputeManager.pre_start_hook which calls update_available_resource where we could still hit the VirtDriverNotReady error.

There is also a post_start_hook we could implement in the compute manager but I'm not sure if it would help because, at least in our CI jobs, ironic might still not be setup yet.

Can we create the sdk connection on the first call to the ironic API somehow? I know the ironic client wrapper code in nova wraps python-ironicclient, and presumably that would have some kind of logic like that?

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/677819/
Sorry, I misread the main loop.

It actually returns 1 for any batch where "there is more to do". The pattern is you run it while 1 and then when it returns 0 it means you're done. See https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6ddfad59354d3a7cb77319e378922c35f6c769d9/nova/cmd/manage.py#L498-L507

Unfortunately I don't see this documented in our doc though:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/cli/nova-manage.html#nova-database

The return codes are: 0 if nothing was archived, 1 if some number of rows were archived, 2 if max_rows is invalid, 3 if no connection could be established to the API DB, 4 if before date is invalid. If automating, this should be run continuously while the result is 1, stopping at 0.

(of course we don't document the return codes in the docs...)

I believe we do not do this through ansible. When we do want to upgrade kubernetes, we would need to edit the kubeadm config and change the kubernetes version. We would then need to run docker login, kubeadm config images pull, and docker logout just like I did in bringup_kubemaster.yml in the review.

this update does a "kubeadm config image pull" before the "kubeadm init". In the upgrade case, we would have to run docker login, kubeadm config images pull, and docker logout to prepull images like the kubeadm init case in this review. Otherwise, it pulls without credentials. Only difference is, we need to update the kubeadm config to the kubernetes version we are upgrading to. This ensures "kubeadm config image pull" pulls down the correct kubernetes versions

If we are upgrading k8s, we would be using the "kubeadm upgrade apply" command described here:
https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/kubeadm/kubeadm-upgrade-1-15/

``[libvirt]/images_rbd_pool`` already exists and is used for instance disks when ``[libvirt]/images_type`` is set to rbd:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/ebd0500b6ae928cfcabd2c5182ca7e6294257a9c/nova/conf/libvirt.py#L881-L883

When images_type=rbd, then snapshots are more nova-managed and Glance is only informed of their existence. In images_type=default, it may make sense to configure that to whatever Glance actually uses for images (even when transferred directly).

This option (images_rbd_pool) may therefore be configured accordingly based on what images_type is. When the snapshot behavior of this change is active, then obviously images_type is NOT rbd, hence images_rbd_pool is not then in use for instances disks.

Unrelated to this, the images_rbd_pool is mislabeled now, saying "The RADOS pool in which rbd volumes are stored". That sounds like it comes from the era of nova-volume. Nevertheless, when Nova does create anything in Ceph, it would go to this pool.

Glance?

It seems like it would be possible to set up a new job with only RBD-backed glance and cinder, for the purposes of fully testing this out. I'm not sure we would want it running on every change, so perhaps we could make it a periodic job or an experimental job.

Aside from that, we will want new unit tests that verify the behavior of trying the direct download/upload when direct_location points to RBD and the fall back to try the HTTP download/upload.

specs/train/approved/server-status-unkno.message:
Question: I actually wasn't sure whether to do it this way vs calling the get_instance_host_status API [1] and showing UNKNOWN if host status is UNKNOWN. Yet another option is showing UNKNOWN if host status != UP. With host_status != UP, I was concerned whether that could be considered leaking hypervisor details because host_status can also be DOWN, MAINTENANCE, or NONE.

Anyone have any opinion on what's the best way?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/fa37cf2/nova/compute/api.py#L4814

Without knowledge of other information about the host, I'm not sure what the harm of leaking the status of said host via instance status would be. I would actually rather explicitly look for HostStatus.DOWN rather than != UP. Being in maintenance does not imply any instance issues. It simply implies that no new instances can be scheduled there.

Yeah, good point. I came to the same conclusion after thinking about it more (that, for example, MAINTENANCE doesn't necessarily mean disruption to the instance). So probably best not to show UNKNOWN for MAINTENANCE and the other states.

I just pushed a new PS that proposes showing server status UNKNOWN when service_is_up != True. None of the other statuses available via the get_instance_host_status method (MAINTENANCE, [forced] DOWN, or NONE) necessarily imply anything about the instance's status.

Could some of the performance impact be mitigated by only calling get_instance_host_status if the instance status is ACTIVE? If Nova has already definitively declared the instance as SHUTOFF or ERROR that would seem to indicate that we're not in an UNKNOWN state.

the flip side of both of these is if the instance is actually fine but the operator is just doing maintenance  on the compute agent this might confuse  end users who can still actully ssh into the instance but can not manage it.

since instance can be running when they are in an unknown state that may result in more support tickets during some maintenance operations as the end user expect it to be active.

maybe. it is leaking the fact the nova compute agent is not currently managing the instance on that host or that it is but something is preventing the control plane from talking ot the compute agent on that host.

if this was admin only be defualt then i totally would agree.
im not sure this is enough of a leak for me to be concerned we are leaking info however so im more meh on the implication of this chagne in behavior.

This also means that all the server operations that is allowed on ACTIVE instance will be allowed on UNKNOWN instance as well. Or vica versa operations that are not allowed on ACTIVE instance (like start) will not be allowed on UNKNOWN instance.

This leads to a minor issue with error messages like:

  $ openstack server start my-vm
  Cannot 'start' instance 57a74a07-ffb4-44d8-b9b6- 
  11c74551baa7 while it is in vm_state active (HTTP 409) 
  (Request-ID: req-2f0af0e7-64aa-4866-a03d-0f2157c2603c)

as it will still talk about ACTIVE instance even if the instance is previously reported as UNKNOWN.

personally as a non admin i think the only instnace operation we shoudl support for unknow instace is delete.

as an admin i can see attpemting other operation but i dont think we should attpemt other operations for non admin users.

Yes, that is true. I am imagining that users would be OK with the inconsistency if it means they get some hint about real instance status instead of always ACTIVE when possibly not really active.

Here's a link to the code where UNKNOWN is similarly used for down cell support:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/1ca69e8/nova/api/openstack/compute/views/servers.py#L150

I have a feeling this will become a slippery slope because someone will fail to heed any warning about UNKNOWN, try something with the server and it will work - or not - and they'll be confused and still complain and want us to do more validation when checking instance state in the API when performing some operation because the view builder said it was UNKNOWN.

Similarly I could see notification consumers saying they want the same kind of UNKNOWN status sent in notifications. Note that we don't reflect host_status in the instance notifications today so notification consumers really don't have any alternatives.

I guess I don't see it that way because to me, this proposal is a best effort don't-boil-the-ocean attempt to be more transparent to users. A small effort to improve server status from a cosmetic standpoint. I suppose we could worry about whether if we give an inch, will people want to take a mile later, but I wasn't thinking about it that way.

This is a pretty weak argument IMO, there are any number of client-side libraries out there. Also, are you only talking about server list here? Because "nova show" with the proper microversion and auth should show the host_status in the detailed output for a given server.
Yes, talking about server list here -- I missed mentioning the context.

If you took the policy route and just let operators supply their own override and keep the API locked down to system users by default, you could filter things accordingly in the nova API [0]. Since you have a context object, you should be able to determine the difference in users. Example policy:

  "os_compute_api:servers:show:host_status": "(role:reader and system_scope:all) or (role:reader and target.project_id)"

[0] https://pasted.tech/pastes/d7363625b6f8b52d68b6ab9515f8e796cb989e66.raw

Sure - you'll just to overload the policy stuff a little bit. You could do something like:

[0] https://pasted.tech/pastes/191423e7b910a47b545768d194554ab362cd1045.raw

Oh, duh. Thanks. We already have a 'context.is_admin' that == 'role:admin' essentially. So after checking policy, we could just check context.is_admin before showing all host_status... but then no one could configure non-admin to see host_status if they wanted to allow that.

Even if it were possible to get finer grain here (guess we could by adding another policy rule), we have a customer ask essentially to not "lie" about the server status being ACTIVE if we know the host status to be UNKNOWN.

> Even if it were possible to get finer grain here (guess we could by adding another policy rule), we have a customer ask essentially to not "lie" about the server status being ACTIVE if we know the host status to be UNKNOWN.

What about power_state and probably other parts of the API related to the server that are based on compute service level information?

I think Dan mentioned this in the ML thread but if we're going to return the status as UNKNOWN then we likely need to go all the way and only return the partial response like in the down cell case and assume we can't even read information out of the cell database so you're just going to get basic information from the pieces we can pull out of the API DB.

Thanks, that is interesting. That code block is imagining what's possible in the future, when nova is no longer using the 'admin' role to signify an admin user, yeah?

IIUC, that isn't possible today, in a world where end users do not request system-scoped tokens and instead use the 'admin' role to auth as admin/system. A user with the 'admin' role would have context.project_id set to something, right? So in that code block, they would only be able to see UNKNOWN and not all the possible host_status.

I'm just trying to determine whether we can do something similar to what you describe in the old-school way today or not.

as a customer that has an sla with a cloud provider where if an instance is not active i get competation for the downtime to i get compenstaion for an instance in the unkonw state?

as a normal user will i be billed for it?

exposing unknown to an unprivileged end-user has business impacts. if i was offering a production service and i had a cloud native app i proable want to kill it and deploy another instance just as i would if the server was in error.

but in the same case if i have such an app i likely have a monitroing system deployed and can tell that already because my app has not phoned home in x secons or maybe it has an i know its actully still active.

so yes this could be usefult but im not sure i want normal users to be able to see the unknown state by defualt. i like controlling it by policy and defualting to admin only as i think this is generally a useful thing.

I guess I don't understand why we can't just keep it simple and show something more accurate than ACTIVE in server status as a cosmetic thing for the end user. I was thinking UNKNOWN is a nice hint for the user that other fields might not be accurate -- proceed with caution. Comparing what we have today (always ACTIVE) to what's proposed, I don't see how it's not a small improvement.

I think this is irrelevant. Long-term we want to move off novaclient and use OSC and by default OSC is going to request 2.1 and so the uninformed user (your customer in this case) won't even get the UNKNOWN status thing they are looking for (by default anyway). But it could be anything that consumes the API, like ansible, the openstacksdk, etc.

FWIW, our customer isn't uninformed any longer after we explained how things work today, but they have a fair point "why show server status as ACTIVE when there's a way to tell it might not actually be ACTIVE." Why willfully show an incorrect status when there's a way to show that something might be off? That is how they are thinking about it and based on a couple of responses from operators on the ML thread, they think about it the same way too.

I guess it also helps to comment on the correct patch set...

Could some of the performance impact be mitigated by only calling get_instance_host_status if the instance status is ACTIVE? If Nova has already definitively declared the instance as SHUTOFF or ERROR that would seem to indicate that we're not in an UNKNOWN state.
Yes, I think that's a good idea and reduces the overall impact.

I was responding specifically to you seeming to agree with Erik here:

> Yes, I think that's a good idea and reduces the overall impact.

i.e. only do the service is up UNKNOWN thing if the status would otherwise be ACTIVE.

This is another slippery slope and why I don't like this proposal. Consider any other number of statuses related the underlying host status:

https://developer.openstack.org/api-guide/compute/server_concepts.html#server-status

Like HARD_REBOOT, MIGRATING, PAUSED, SHELVED, VERIFY_RESIZE, etc. Let's say one of the computes is down when I try to confirm a resize but because the API still showed VERIFY_RESIZE rather than UNKNOWN, now I'm going to open a ticket saying the API shouldn't "lie to me". Then what do we do - have another microversion to handle non-ACTIVE cases as well?

> I was responding specifically to you seeming to agree with Erik
 > here:
 > 
 > > Yes, I think that's a good idea and reduces the overall impact.
 > 
 > i.e. only do the service is up UNKNOWN thing if the status would
 > otherwise be ACTIVE.

Oh, sorry, yes I was agreeing with him. But when you brought up the other possible server statuses, I'm not sure it would be the right move to pick and choose which get translated to UNKNOWN. It seemed to make sense that ERROR state could be left as-is because it's a terminal state, but thinking about all of the others, it's probably best to just show any as UNKNOWN if not service_is_up.
Well, this proposal covers those cases too, right? I used ACTIVE as the primary example but the proposal is to show UNKNOWN if service_is_up is False, for server list and server show.

This is not the same as what you're proposing. Unless I'm mistaken, you're proposing to just mask the returned status as UNKNOWN and leave everything else the same assuming we can reach the cell database to get the instance related information. The UNKNOWN status we have now returns a partial result of the server response body because we literally can't build the full response because we can't get the details from the cell database.

I considered it to be the same because it's intentionally generic. It says, "UNKNOWN: The state of the server is unknown. It could be because a part of the infrastructure is temporarily down (see Handling Down Cells for more information). Contact your cloud provider."

To me, that's reads that UNKNOWN means it's possible a cell is down but it's written to encompass any unknown status and not a contract that UNKNOWN must mean a cell is down.

ansible/roles/haproxy-config/templates/h.message:
When internal TLS is enabled, it's assumed that if local backend is unavailable, connection will be forwarded to remote HAProxy - for that to work all HAProxy must listen on some interface.

For now I'm listening on the external interface, to not clash with backends that are already listening on the same port, but the internal interface - not sure if that's the best approach.

Also, we're doing that only for HTTP services - that lets us keep existing configuration for TCP services (rabbit, mariadb and and memcached).
P.S. `backup` means that we're not doing loadbalancing between backends which is probably not what we want
If `kolla_verify_tls` is true, then skip certificate verification on remote haproxies.

networking_vpp/agent/server.py.message: Wouldn't this need a lock?  It's hard to be sure that this is eventlet-safe.

Ok, confirmed from python doc:
https://docs.python.org/dev/library/collections.html?highlight=deque#collections.deque

Deques support thread-safe, memory efficient appends and pops from either side of the deque with approximately the same O(1) performance in either direction

Since I am only using a single atomic operation such as an append and a popleft, on the deque, I believe is should be safe to use it without a lock because python has a GIL, which ensures that only one greenlet can run at a time. If it were a compound operation such as an extend, we would need a lock. Correct?
OK, but this doesn't bind the tap interface until the next bind call.  How do I know that bind call will come at the right time?

The self.data.bind call above should bind the tap interface. This call will ensure that the external devices detected in the linux kernel by the callback function _consider_external_device is added as well. Do you see an issue?

doc/source/admin/examples/zuul-config/zu.message: Let's not link to the infra manual.
I don't think we should promote clean check.  Zuul's own Zuul doesn't use it.

We call this system, where check jobs must be run to completion before gate "clean check".  It should not be necessary for most projects, but the OpenStack project wanted it (because the gate queue is so long that people could not be relied upon not to enqueue flaky changes).

We no longer use this in the Zuul tenant.  I think we should recommend our own configuration to new users, as the workflow where gate supercedes check is much nicer.  See our config at:
https://opendev.org/zuul/project-config/src/branch/master/zuul.d/pipelines.yaml

specs/approved/armada_time_metrics.rst.message:
I think this section should answer the following questions:

1. What are the metrics Armada will capture? (e.g. full deployment time, upgrade time, wait time, install time)

2. How is each metric defined? (e.g. full deployment time captures the install/upgrade, wait, and test times for a release)

3. What data must be captured for the metrics? How/where is the data stored? How is it captured? (the capturing part appears to be called out in this spec, using a timer built-in to armada)

5. How are the metrics communicated?
Added some answers, need to flesh it out more and look into the data capture requirements/locations

Another alternative would be using time data from Helm. I can't speak to whether or not this is more/less reliable or incomplete.

But that's also the purpose of this spec, so that would be helpful to explore and represent here.
Looking into this further, will add once more understood
let's make sure this gets addressed before merging
Fleshed out some, seeing what else may be needed
should probably break these into a numbered list

I thought the main idea of the spec was to expose an endpoint within armada which could be scraped by prometheus and thus monitoring of these chart deployment etc. could be included in the LMA framework.

I am not clear if we are achieving the same with the proposed solution or how would prometheus be able to scrape the time metrics with the proposed solution? can it be clarified?
Let me double check the details for the spec request. Marking as -1 WF until clarified.
Probably "delays", not "errors". But "errors" is still fine.
Please, check how it conforms to https://airshipit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/service-logging-conventions.html , some changes might be needed.
There is correct logging format below, so removed this.
should read "While similar to the proposed change"
Update Armada documentation, listing log format, and use case with CRD/Prometheus; update https://airshipit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/service-logging-conventions.html if it would be needed.

the split between the tiller install/upgrade call and the armada wait logic is highly dependent on whether the tiller native wait logic is enabled (wait.native.enabled flag in armada/Chart doc). So I think the more useful metric is just the overall metric is the time from initial tiller install/upgrade to end of armada wait logic which can be considered the "deployment time".
simply logging them will not allow them to be scraped by Prometheus or exported to a CRD. They need to be stored in an explicit object model for that.

0x8086 is discovered from sysfs, we should convert it to "intel" here. I think it is better than hard code "intel" here.
It will be simpler to just set DRIVER_NAME="intel" and use that. This seems to obscure the change and the intent.
Just for easy change when we want change the name in the future. Cause there are several assignment of driver_name.

FYI, 8086 is always Intel -- Intel's first microprocessor was 8086. Intel devices generally should have that vendor ID of 8086 but it is possible/conceivable that some cores from former Altera may get shipped with a different PCI ID. Even then the driver name should be Intel.

Do you see this driver being used with any vendor other than Intel? That is not the intent.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I see context for this in the code itself, but this does sound like something that there should be a bug and possibly a reno for. Right?

It's not really a bug in that there's no incorrect reporting of bytes available for deployers who deploy one OSD per disk as recommended by the ceph documentation: "Running multiple OSDs on a single disk–irrespective of partitions–is NOT a good idea." [1].

But for deployers who _do_ deploy more than one OSD per disk, this change will cause a change from an inflated bytes available number (multiplied by the number of configured replicas) to a correct bytes available number (inflated number divided by the number of configured replicas = correct number).

I'm torn about it because those seeing a wrong number are deploying incorrectly/against the rules specified in the ceph docs.

But since we _can_ do this to improve the calculation for people who are deploying incorrectly, we might as well.

Do what to do? Bug? Reno? Anyone have an opinion? I lean toward reno only, but happy to do whatever.

[1] http://docs.ceph.com/docs/luminous/start/hardware-recommendations/#hard-disk-drives

I am also referring to the same DPDK device binding.   The SRIOV CNI plugin permits specifying the binding device and can therefore handle the loading of the kernel modules and the binding to the VFIO-PCI device.   This way, any DPDK based application (including OVS-DPDK) doesn't have to have extended privileges to perform this binding on the host.

We are already adding support for the DPDK device binding for containerized workloads, so there would be no additional work.  The data network association is the same method we use for the current vswitch port assignment, therefore it would align both containerized deployments.

The global vswitch_type should not be leveraged for containerized services.  The intent of supporting "none" is to disable the host vswitch in support of optionality in the containerized deployment.  I recommend that you handle the selection of vswitch deployment type based on K8s node labels and Helm specific configuration options.

How to control DPDK workloads by k8s label?
We don't create additional pod for dpdk support. If we add label openvswitch-dpdk=enabled, which pod will this label affect?

I recommend that you use a K8s node label to indicate if OVS on that node should enable DPDK.  eg. openvswitch-dpdk=enabled. 
This will permit the selection of the OVS datapath on a per-node basis rather than globally.
That is one special property that can be used for scheduling, and in this particular case I think it would be ideal since we would want to control the placement of DPDK workloads.

There was only one case for containerized ovs. But now we are going to have two, 1) containerized ovs 2) containerized ovs with dpdk. So how do we distinguish dpdk enabled or not if we have only vswitch_type 'none'? We need a variable to indicate dpdk eanbled or not. openvswitch helm plugin[1] needs the variable to generate correct values.yaml

[1] https://opendev.org/starlingx/config/src/branch/master/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/helm/openvswitch.py

It's great to support per-node selection of dpdk.
But I would prefer to use some other property(maybe add a new one) of node to indicate dpdk-enabled more than k8s label. Because k8s label has its special usage(pod schedule).
okay, if we have done things in this way, I can follow it.

Labels are merely meta-data that can be attached to objects.  The only special property of a label is that it can be used as a selector when scheduling, but it doesn't have to be used that way.  It can be used to identity attributes of a particular resource.

Therefore my recommendation is to assign the openvswitch-dpdk=enabled label to the node so that the OVS configuration can use that data to identify the initialization properties for the OVS process (i.e. other_config:dpdk-init=true).  The OVS Helm plugin can check for this label key:value when generating the Helm overrides to setup the appropriate data path properties for the Pod.

We have other Helm plugins that follow this model.  You can look at the existing Helm plugins to see how they are used in this way.  Nova is an example that uses a label for identifying remote storage.

I am not following your comment.

K8S is going to launch the pod in the k8s cgroup. 
This cgroup has a cpuset which for an openstack node is the platform cores. This means the pod can only run on those cpu's

This really has nothing to do with hugepages. 
Can you describe how the pmd threads will get pinned to the desired cores.

A similar problem existed with containerizing nova, libvirt, and QEMU. The issue with using cgroups/cpusets is that all child cpusets must be a subset of the parent. The solution for QEMU/kvm was to change existing libvirt/qemu configuration to not share the cgroup, so it ends up using the cgroup 'machine.slice' instead which is orthagonal to k8s-infra. The QEMU case was achieved by disabling all relavent cgroup controllers like this with helm override:
'qemu': {'cgroup_controllers': ["cpu", "cpuacct", "cpuset", "freezer", "net_cls", "perf_event"], } . They get created under machine.slice instead.

All controllers are mounted by default by systemd. I create the specific machine.slice directory and configure it here: puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/manifests/compute.pp

Note that libvirt/qemu will automatically create the machine.slice, but this allows me to customize settings.
The choice of 'machine.slice' was to align with systemd  / machinectl / qemu assumption for virtual machines, but the cgroup name is an arbitrary string. You can likely just reuse machine.slice or create an entirely new directory.

Take a look at how libvirt init pod packages 'cgset' to dynamically create mounts for other controllers, including hugepages.

Seems this is related to your previous comment. If we remove cpuset from k8s-infra group, the pod can see all the CPUs. So we can pin pmd threads to the isolated CPUs.
On the standard profile worker node, the vm cores are not isolated with isolcpus and cannot be in order to supported shared vcpu's.

No, you cannot move cpuset from the k8s-infra group. All pods will be launched in this cgroup. If the cpu is not in the cpuset then the container will not see that cpu.

If you remove the reduced cpuset from the k8s-infra group then the VM cores will not be isolated (pods will run on those cores as well)which will not be acceptable. Please review Jim's comments again. You are going to need to leverage a similar strategy for OVS-DPDK.

charms_openstack/charm/utils.py.message:
I don't think this is very robust as a solution; i.e. it's possible that '.venv' isn't the directory that the venv lives in (it's a convention) and so the function would transparently fail and NOT do what the function says it does.

I don't actually think there *is* a good way to detect the venv apart from looking at virtualenv ENV variables. But PEP405 doesn't even mention ENV vars, so maybe it's not actually possible.

I think it would be better to actually construct a PATH without the venv (e.g. using /etc/environment's PATH) rather than trying to detect or use tox's idea of a virtualenv.

I searched PEP405 for standard ways of doing this and came up with nothing, just as you did.

What we can rely on from the standard is that the virtualenv path is inserted at the beginning of the path.

The name was chosen by investigating how our environment is set up by the layer we currently use for distribution of all of the consumers of this library.

I chose this approach because I had concerns with what would happen if the user has customized their path somehow, I guess using /etc/environment for that is a convention we can rely on.
I wonder if these two functions shouldn't be in charm-helpers?
